citation.article-title: Ottowia thiooxydans gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel facultatively anaerobic, N2O-producing bacterium isolated from activated sludge, and transfer of Aquaspirillum gracile to Hylemonella gracilis gen. nov., comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Ottowia (Ot.to′wi.a. N.L. fem. n. Ottowia of Ottow, named after Johannes C. G. Ottow, who made several interesting contributions to our knowledge of denitrification in soil and activated sludge).
Cells are Gram-negative, non-motile and rod-shaped.
No spores or cysts are formed.
Polyhydroxyalkanoate granules are stored as intracellular reserve material.
Generally, carboxylic acids and amino acids are utilized as substrates.
Facultatively anaerobic growth by nitrate reduction.
No aerobic chemolithoautotrophic growth with hydrogen as substrate.
Major cellular fatty acids are 16 : 1ω7c, 18 : 1ω7c and 16 : 0.
Phylogenetically affiliated to the family Comamonadaceae within the β-Proteobacteria.
The type species is Ottowia thiooxydans.
